column5: Reason

column2: Workload is spread over the whole team (one team member is often Xtimes more productive than the others...but nevertheless, here is a track record that everyone is contributing a lot)
column5: Number of commits show a wide range of numbers, and it looks like it was not equally distributed.
438 total commits have been made.

column2: Number of commits: by different people
column5: git shortlog -s -n
12 Issues but all closed
All the issues are closed

column2: Docs: doco generated, format not ugly
column5: Formatting is neat and is easy to naviagte

column2: Docs: what: point descriptions of each class/function (in isolation)
column5: Each feature of the end product is exaplained with the available options

column2: Docs: how: for common use cases X,Y,Z mini-tutorials showing worked examples on how to do X,Y,Z
column5: There are no tutorials as such, but most of the features have examples of the end result. No details or samples of GUI portal

column2: Docs: why: docs tell a story, motivate the whole thing, deliver a punchline that makes you want to rush out and use the thing
column5: The concept and examples of outputs are relayed in detail to interest the reader

column2: Docs: short video, animated, hosted on your repo. That convinces people why they want to work on your code.
column5: There is no video and GIF does relay the impact or use case of project
Github is used to host the project
Not used, looks like a dummy file
No code formatter file in workflows
Py Lint used
Coverage tile is also present on the landing page
Nothing else exists
Code coverage is 70

column2: The files CONTRIBUTING.md lists coding standards and lots of tips on how to extend the system without screwing things up
column5: The explanation is in detail

column2: Issues are discussed before they are closed
column5: There are barely any comments on the issues before being closed

column2: Test cases: a large proportion of the issues related to handling failing cases.
column5: None of the issues have the tag corrosponding to that

column2: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools: everyone can get to all tools and files
column5: There are 33 forks of the repo, and everyone was commiting at various times, so we can assume that they tested before commiting.

column2: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. config files in the repo, updated by lots of different people)
column5: As per commit history only a couple of people were active in the time frame of the 4 releases.

column2: Evidence that the whole team is using the same tools (e.g. tutor can ask anyone to share screen, they demonstrate the system running on their computer)
Evidence that the members of the team are working across multiple places in the code base
column5: We can see that someone was commiting on front end of the code, someone was focused on workflows and others on backend.
4 releases published in just 8 days.
